threads.com:
Here's a few summaries of some critic reviews. They all pretty much say the same thing:

>"It is, in almost every way, the transformation I’ve been waiting for – but the grievously poor performance that has come along with it significantly mars this otherwise exciting design evolution." - IGN

>"The huge expansion and changes to the single player campaign are great, the size of the world and the joy of exploration are the best in the series, and the new Pokemon and battle mechanics introduced all sing. However, it’s just impossible to shake the thought of how much better the game would feel if it was on more powerful hardware, or simply ran acceptably on Switch" - VGC

>"We really hope Game Freak can figure out how to smooth out the series’ ongoing performance issues on Switch because they'll certainly rub some players the wrong way — and they’re going to become a serious detriment over time. Scarlet & Violet is most fun and exciting when you're just exploring the world, and while there are many small new details and improvements to the Pokémon formula, it still plays it safe in a few areas" - Nintendo Life

>"While Scarlet and Violet aren't a complete reinvention of the formula, and technical performance issues certainly hold them back, they're still an essential leap forward – both in storytelling and gameplay mechanics" - GamesHub

>"While undercooked presentation and visual issues hold the games back, Pokemon Scarlet and Violet are still the best mainline Pokemon games in years. " - GameSpot

Seems like there's a decent Pokemon under the horrendous frame rates and visual issues.

It's funny, Sword and Shield got high praise for being lackluster in all aspects. Scarlet and Violet seems to be a full experience this time, but is completely getting lambasted for performance issues alone.

Then you have examples like Corviknight, Aegislash, Gengar, Chandelure, and Volcarona, all very mainstream in their popularity, but I'll be damned if they aren't clean designs. I've noticed a big surge in Sableye love in recent years, which is cool to see having loved it for so long.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>52171554
Controlled chaos. Z moves are similar in that regard but they were generally not nearly as impactful due to being one-time use. Megas require you to attach an item, so you know who you're going to use the gimmick on before the battle starts. They have a limited number of pokemon they're given to, and in several cases you may prefer to use a normal item slot instead, so they don't have to appear in every battle. Dynamax and Teras can be used on anyone at any time. You might have an idea of who you want to pick for the role but the gimmicks are far less committal than megas.

It weighs things a little too heavily in favor of prediction rather than reaction, when they should be more balanced. Your planning is focused on who the gimmick mon even is to begin with rather than what you're going to do about it. This is ubiquitous with Tera and Dynamax, whereas it has to be a deliberate ploy with megas.

>>52178427
To start, you gotta play through the fight once to get an idea for what fast attacks each of his pokemon have. The first pokemon he sends out is always persian and the third one is always Mewtwo (for the moment.)

Persian's fast attacks are either scratch (normal type) or feint attack (dark type). If it uses scratch, send out a ghost, rock, and or steel type pokemon to start. Ideally something that has low cost charge moves as he's going to shield whatever you charge attack him with twice.

Second pokemon I don't remember but you can definitely look it up. You deal with it the same way. Look up what fast moves the pokemon has with https://gamepress.gg/pokemongo/, figure out which one was used against you the first time you battled him, and add a pokemon to your party that's highly resistant to it.

Lastly for mewtwo, your best bet is using a bulky dark type pokemon like Tyranitar since dark double resists psychic and mewtwo only has psychic fast moves. Psychic and Steel types also resist psychic moves so if you have a metagross, try using him. If you can post a screenshot of your top 12 highest CP pokemon I can try to give you some suggestions.

>>52178549
Forgot to talk about feint attack.
If the Persian has feint attack then send out a fighting, dark, or fairy pokemon. Like the other person responded to you said, getting Giovanni to use up his two shields asap is the early goal so something like Lucario with power-up punch or another quick filling charge move is ideal.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>52178427
To add on to the others, something important to take advantage of is the fact that he will attack right away when the fight begins, but whenever you manually switch Pokemon or use a charged move, he won't attack for five seconds.

I was piloting a low level account, so what I did for the win was start with Trevenant, who could easily tank Persian's attacks, build up some charge, and then switched out for my more fragile shield-breaker, which ultimately allowed it to stay on the field longer and do more damage.

threads.com:
First time I've been sorely disappointed with the music in a Pokemon game. I quickly searched the internet for why that's the case and guess what I found?

Honestly, every track in this game just becomes boring and noisy after listening for 2 minutes. Legends Arceus had tracks constantly switching styles while being memorable and also giving the nostalgia tip-offs. The trainer battle theme from that game is my favorite.

Here in SV, it feels like the tracks start off strong but Toby Fox quickly loses any idea of where to go with it and ends up making a chaotic mess of junk difficult to follow along and have a feel for after just a minute or two.

I heard he got very little material to work with for inspiration, and I don't have a problem with it per se but I think his style is just not meant for Pokemon. Whatever the vampires at GameFreak compose is a better fit for my ears.

God, this is just dissapointing

Then the random poke balls, but they're small and I can ignore them
Then what looks like awkward handling, but it's ok because I'll try to stick to flat ground and won't intentionally crash into obstacles
Then the camera clipping out of bounds, but it's ok because I'll avoid battles in narrow spaces
Finally, the performance issues on OG hardware....
I can't cope anymore, I want to like Pokemon, I really do. I grew up with this franchise, but this is just so bad
When there's framerate problems, dipping to 20 and BELOW FFS, that's where I just can't cope.
Also that's when I realized I do care about the earlier problems too (except MAYBE the starter evos), it reeks of no polish, infested with bugs and glitches, and dissapointment
What a damn fucking shame, I hope they fix it, I'll at least cope with that.
But until then, I think I'm out. I've only played like 5-6 mainline and 3 spinoff pokemon titles, so I think I'll check out all the games I didn't play.
I hope you guys have fun with this at least.

Elden Ring has too much copy paste content and the atrocious balancing makes every weapon and every build unsatisfying to use in some way or another

Xenoblade 3 had some amazing high points among an otherwise incredibly dull plot with no real stakes ever being raised, no significant losses suffered for what's supposed to be a story about war and rebellion, an atrociously bad final chapter, and horrible combat balancing that ends up just being about spamming smash combos, if you can input things fast enough you can theoretically finish every fight in the game in less than 3 seconds
